Topic.Title: power GOLDMAN !!!!!!!

Message.Msg: yeah, last Dec 11, GS put a sell rating on yhoo with a price of $14. Now, they they put a buy rating (after Yahoo has already cashed the first Alibaba check). I am sure that GS first covered all their shorts and bought while it was down. So, did GS buy last Friday or was it Yhoo doing a buy back, or some other institutional investor. IMO, Yhoo should see lots of upgrades as the value of their Asian assets is high, they have cash, no debt, and folks have placed almost no value on what really is a valuable core company - all just my opinion (and for once I agree with GS - even if I still detest the company for what they did leading up to and through 2008).

Message.Title: Upgrade a game changer
Message.Msg: Valuation and direction of company is finally starting to get attention of big boys. Big money left Yahoo when the whole MSFT deal collapsed leaving the stock price at the mercy of manipulators and shorts. This could start bringing big money back into the stock.

Topic.Title: Upgrade a game changer

Message.Msg: Agreed. It's finally the time for Yahoo. The experience and vision from a new CEO and new CFO will be key to success.

Topic.Title: Upgrade a game changer

Message.Msg: I am surprised that there were not more upgrades, and faster. The Alibaba money is hard cash. It demonstrates value of assets held by Yahoo!. The 17/1 PE ratio only involves the earnings from the core not the Asian assets. Subtract out the Asian assets and the share buy back and you have a company near 1/1 or lower o.x/1, with no debt, an income stream, lots of eyes....a bazaarly unrealistic low evaluation - IMO. When and if institutional players decide they want to gobble up value the price will go up substantially. - again IMO

Message.Msg: "We believe the value of Yahoo's balance sheet assets and the core business are worth more than the current stock price and that capital allocation actions over the coming months will serve as the catalyst to drive that revaluation," said analyst Heath Terry. Goldman said it's removing its not rated designation for Yahoo.

Topic.Title: Are you buying or selling Yahoo at $16?

Message.Msg: The next step up for yahoo requires folks to feel comfortable buying above $16. At present it can't even push past 15.90 with the GS upgrade. Twice in the past couple of weeks it has gone over 16 then it has been sold off [I sold most of my trading shares after the first run up past 16]. Seems to me that if it can get above 16 now it will stay there as most have already sold off their trading shares in that range. The question is: After two failed trips above 16 will people pay 16 for yahoo!? IMO, if the price can sustain itself past 16.3s level it should go up. Unfortunately, there are a lot of folks who simply want a few cents and continue to play with Yahoo!s short range volatility (in recent years for every bit of good news there has been an equal or greater batch of bad news).

Message.Title: Marissa Mayer Tells Yahoo Employees Products Must Ship In 6 Months, Or Don't Bother
Message.Msg: According to sources familiar with the details of the meeting, one of her major changes to Yahoo is how the company will decide which products to ship. Mayer's rule: If a new product can't be shipped in six months, and if it doesn't have a realistic shot of reaching 100 million users or generate $100 million toward the company's top line, then Yahoo will no longer bother. Mayer picked up this pace from Google, where she made her fame and fortune as a product manager/marketer. SAI

Message.Title: Goldman Sachs analyst sees surge for Yahoo stock
Message.Msg: Goldman Sachs analyst Heath Terry isn't convinced Yahoo CEO Marissa Mayer will be able to engineer a quick turnaround, but he still believes the troubled Internet company's stock will surge by more than 40 percent during the next year. Terry made a case for Yahoo shares rising from Wednesday's closing price of $15.61 to $22, giving them a "Buy" rating. His rationale: Investors still haven't fully appreciated the value of Yahoo's cash and investments in Asia. In a research note late Wednesday, he said he also expects the stock to get a slight lift as Mayer shares more details about her long-term plan to revive the company's revenue growth.

Topic.Title: Goldman Sachs analyst sees surge for Yahoo stock

Topic.Title: Are you buying or selling Yahoo at $16?

Message.Msg: Perhaps everyone remembers you telling them to "buy buy buy" in the $30s and the $20s. Remember your gleeful ranting that the talking heads at Yahoo! should hold out for more... a lot more... a few years ago when Microsoft offered to buy them out? That kind of set the stage for years of bad advise from you. And that seems to be the one area where you have never failed to disappoint. I'll answer you in spite of my ongoing rule to not fraternize with goofballs. YHOO has been dead money for years. I'm holding quite a few RIMM shares though. Watch me sell covered calls tomorrow AM. It's as good a money tree as YHOO used to be back when the baggies had hope.
